abstract.text: An interface for configuring a rule-based list of options.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A rule editor lets the user visually create and configure a list of options that are expressed as a predicate (as described in

). Each row displayed by the rule editor represents a particular path down a tree of choices. The rule editor’s delegate provides the tree of choices to be displayed. The rule editor presents those choices to the user as a row of popup buttons, static text fields, and custom views.
to an ordered collection (such as an instance of
). Each object in the collection should have the following properties:
An integer representing the type of the row (
An ordered to-many relation (such as an instance of
) containing the directly nested subrows for the given row.
An ordered to-many relation containing the display values for the row.
An ordered to-many relation containing the criteria for the row.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
A control that defines an area on the screen that a user clicks to trigger an action.
A control that displays a color value and lets the user change that color value.
A button with a pull-down menu and a default action.
A specialized view, such as a button or text field, that notifies your app of relevant events using the target-action design pattern.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
A display of image data in a frame.
A visual representation of a level or quantity, using discrete values.
A control for selecting an item from a list.
A defined set of rules that allows the editing of predicate objects.
An interface that provides visual feedback to the user about the status of an ongoing task.
An interface for configuring a rule-based list of options.
Specifies a type for nesting modes.
Specifies a type for row types.
Adds a row to the receiver.
A Boolean value that indicates whether all the rows can be removed.
Returns the currently chosen items for a given row.
The criteria key path.
The rule editor’s delegate.
Returns the chosen values for a given row.
The display values key path.
The formatting dictionary for the rule editor.
The name of the rule editor’s strings file.
Adds a new row of a given type at a given location.
A Boolean value that determines whether the rule editor is editable.
The rule editor’s nesting mode.
The number of rows in the rule editor.
Returns the index of the parent of a given row.
The rule editor’s predicate.
Returns the predicate for a given row.
Instructs the receiver to refetch criteria from its delegate.
Instructs the receiver to regenerate its predicate by invoking the corresponding delegate method.
Removes the row at a given index.
Removes the rows at given indexes.
Returns the index of the row containing a given value.
The class used to create a new row in the “rows” binding.
The rule editor’s row height.
Returns the type of a given row.
The key path for the row type.
This notification is posted to the default notification center whenever the view’s rows change.
Sets in the receiver the indexes of rows that are selected.
The indexes of the rule editor’s selected rows.
Modifies the row at a given index to contain the given items and values.
Returns the immediate subrows of a given row.
The key path for the subrows.

Display one or more buttons in a single horizontal group.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
Informs the view that it has been added to a new view hierarchy.
Display a list of values in a pop-up menu that lets the user select a value or type in a custom value.
Display a calendar date and provide controls for editing the date value.
A display of a file system path or virtual path information.
Provide a text field that is optimized for text-based search interfaces.
Display a range of values from which the user selects a single value.
Handle user input by connecting buttons, sliders, and other controls to your app’s code using the target-action design pattern.

abstract.text: A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
